summary: Paul Merson and Andros Townsend have resumed their dispute after Townsend played for Tottenham in a 0-0 draw against Burnley. Merson criticized Townsend's inclusion in the England squad, but admitted he was wrong after Townsend scored against Italy. Despite this, Merson continued to comment on Townsend's performance, reigniting tensions between them.

Chelsea has shown interest in acquiring 22-year-old Japanese forward Yoshinori Muto from FC Tokyo. Muto, who has played for FC Tokyo since 2013 and has 16 goals in 37 appearances, is also set to join Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season if he transfers to Chelsea. FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane denies that the transfer is linked to Chelsea's sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber. If Muto joins Chelsea, he would become the first Japanese player to represent the club. Muto has also earned 11 caps for the Japanese national team and recently graduated from Keio University with an economics degree.

A large-scale study found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight as toddlers. Researchers from Finland compared the weight and height of over 12,000 two-year-olds with records of antibiotic prescriptions. The study suggests that repeated antibiotic use during infancy increases the likelihood of being overweight, especially in boys. Antibiotics may contribute to weight gain by altering gut bacteria, potentially increasing appetite and food absorption. The findings highlight the need for careful antibiotic use in infants to address concerns about the obesity epidemic.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony, an embarrassing moment that was captured on camera by a tourist. The guard, wearing full regalia, lost his footing, dropped his rifle, and slid sideways into the sentry box. Despite the mishap, he quickly recovered and continued with the ceremony. The incident occurred in front of numerous shocked tourists, causing the guard to feel embarrassed. The cause of the fall was speculated to be due to metal protectors on the soles of his boots.

A&E, Lifetime, and History are remaking the 1977 miniseries "Roots" for a 2016 broadcast. The new version, which will be original and contemporary, draws more from Alex Haley's novel and includes input from historians for authenticity. LeVar Burton, who played Kunta Kinte in the original, is co-executive producing the remake. The producers aim to reach both original fans and a new generation of viewers, emphasizing the importance of Kunta Kinte's story in light of recent historical and social contexts.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, has accused palace aides at Clarence House of attempting to force him into an orgy in 1978. The incident occurred on his first day at work and left him traumatized. Lawler claims his complaint was initially ignored, only being passed to the police after months of inaction. The case is part of a broader investigation into historical allegations of child sex abuse involving a VIP paedophile ring. Clarence House has stated they will cooperate with the police investigation.

A couple from Oregon, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy through a rap video set to the theme song from the '90s TV show 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air'. The video, which has garnered over 1.7 million views on YouTube, includes raps about their journey to parenthood and the surprise of finding out they were pregnant. They also shared a sonogram at the end. Jesse is the great-great-grandson of an Oregon pioneer, and the video was created to inform distant relatives about the upcoming arrival. The couple unexpectedly gained significant attention for their creative announcement.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film "Gone With the Wind" sold for $137,000 at auction. The dress, originally slate blue-gray, has faded to light gray due to age. It was part of a collection amassed by James Tumblin, who acquired it for $20 in the 1960s. The auction also featured other high-selling items like a hat worn by Leigh and a suit worn by Clark Gable. "Gone With the Wind," celebrating its 75th anniversary, was based on Margaret Mitchell's novel and starred Leigh and Gable. Hattie McDaniel, who played Mammy, became the first African-American to win an Academy Award.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after slipping between 10 to 12 feet over a railing while being held by his parents. The child was rescued by his parents before emergency services arrived and was treated for minor injuries at MetroHealth Medical Center. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family. The cheetahs did not attack the child, and the exhibit was closed following the incident.

A speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, which previously enforced a 30mph speed limit, has been re-pointed to face the front door of a house. This camera has been non-functional for over two years due to the shutdown of all fixed devices in the West Midlands in March 2013. Instead, mobile cameras and traffic officers have taken over enforcement duties. The camera's redirection is under investigation, and plans for a new pilot project with updated technology do not include this specific camera.

Usain Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medallist, will participate in the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas as part of the Jamaican team from May 2-3. Bolt expressed his readiness and excitement to compete, noting the positive atmosphere from previous years and Jamaica's strong relay tradition. The Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association is pleased with Bolt's participation and expects impressive performances. The full Jamaican team list for the event has not yet been announced.

Neymar and Dani Alves supported Barcelona's basketball team by attending an Euro League game against Real Madrid, which Barcelona won narrowly. Despite this, Real Madrid remain top of the Euro League standings due to a better points difference. Neymar also played for Brazil, winning a 1-0 match against Chile, though he faced tough challenges during the game. Barcelona secured a victory in their recent El Clasico match in La Liga, moving them four points ahead. They will face Celta Vigo in La Liga to aim for a treble of trophies.

The passage describes a significant influx of migrants attempting to reach Italy via the Mediterranean Sea, with a notable increase in rescue operations by the Italian coast guard. Between Friday and Monday, 8,480 migrants were rescued, and on Monday alone, the coast guard received SOS calls from 20 boats. Save the Children reported potential loss of 400 migrants after a ship carrying 550 people capsized near the Libyan coast, but the Italian coast guard has not confirmed this. There has been a recent surge in migrant crossings and rescues, with over 10,000 migrants arriving in Italy in the first three months of 2015 and around 2,000 rescued in the first weekend of April. Migrants primarily come from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit point. Since the beginning of the year, at least 480 migrants have died due to poor conditions and abandonment by smugglers.

Arsene Wenger, Arsenal's manager, explains that he doesn't know the exact reason why Alexis Sanchez chose Arsenal over Liverpool, but is pleased that Sanchez will play for Arsenal instead of against them in their upcoming match. Sanchez, a 26-year-old Chilean forward, joined Arsenal after Barcelona decided to let him leave and was convinced to do so by Wenger's guidance. He has made an immediate impact, scoring 19 goals this season. Wenger acknowledges that Liverpool's interest in Sanchez could have influenced Barcelona's negotiations for Luis Suarez. Wenger praises Sanchez's adaptability and attributes, considering him among the best players. The passage also mentions Wenger's stance on Raheem Sterling, a Liverpool player, and his view on how Brendan Rodgers has managed Liverpool despite losing Suarez and Sturridge.

Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and former Tour de France winner, plans to attempt the hour record in cycling on June 7 at the Olympic Velodrome in London. Wiggins aims to surpass the current record of 52.491 km, set by Australian Rohan Dennis. He hopes to attract a large crowd to support him, with tickets going on sale on April 19. Wiggins, who recently finished his career with Team Sky, is expected to maintain this record for some time.

Serena Williams, a twice French Open champion and World No. 1, faced a challenging match against Sara Errani in the Fed Cup, ultimately winning 4-6 7-6(3) 6-3. Despite the victory, Williams acknowledged that she was unprepared for the clay court conditions, stating that she needs to adjust her game. The U.S. team lost the overall match 3-2, leading to their relegation to World Group II. This loss also marked the first time Williams had lost a Fed Cup singles match. The U.S. captain, Mary Joe Fernandez, emphasized the need for improvement and dedication to return to the World Group.

River Plate is interested in signing Manchester United's striker Radamel Falcao, with whom they have a history, as he spent eight years there before moving to Porto in 2009. Falcao, now 29, has struggled during his loan at Manchester United, scoring only four goals in the Premier League this season. River Plate's vice president, Matias Patanian, expressed their desire to bring Falcao back, stating that "the doors are open." Falcao recently equaled Colombia's all-time goalscoring record with 24 goals while performing well for his national team. He previously scored 34 goals in 90 appearances for River Plate during his four seasons in the first team.

Ella Henderson, a 19-year-old pop star and X Factor finalist, has partnered with the dry shampoo brand Batiste as its official face for the 2015 'Ready For It' campaign. This marks her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson in various hairstyles, including wavy and half-ponytail looks, against a vibrant city backdrop. The partnership was facilitated by the MILES agency and includes a TV advertising campaign featuring her single "Mirror Man." Henderson expressed excitement about the collaboration, noting that she frequently uses Batiste products. Her manager highlighted the natural fit between Henderson's talent and Batiste's popularity among young consumers.

A billboard featuring the officer, Pablo Torres, who shot and killed Aaron Siler, was erected in Kenosha, Wisconsin, causing shock among Siler's family and friends. Siler, 26, was fatally shot after confronting Officer Torres with a weapon on March 14. Torres is on leave pending the investigation. The billboard, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, includes a photograph of Torres and his dog, with the message "Thank you for your support, Kenosha." Family and friends consider it disrespectful, with Siler's mother expressing distress. The police association claims no offense was intended, stating the billboard was to thank the community for support during recent incidents. Siler was wanted on an active felony probation and parole warrant. The shooting occurred 10 days after Torres shot another man, Terry Knight, who was armed with knives; Knight was wounded but not killed. Both shootings are under investigation.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the border with Pakistan. The fighting occurred in the town of Negur and involved a militant group called Jaish al Adal, which claimed responsibility for the attack. The group, a Sunni Muslim organization based in Pakistan's Balochistan province, targets Shiites and opposes Iranian influence in Pakistan. Pakistan has condemned the attack and is investigating the incident, stating that if the militants fled into Pakistan, they would be apprehended.

The passage discusses a political exchange in Japan where a wrestler-turned-politician, Antonio Inoki, questioned Japan's Defense Minister about UFOs from outer space. Defense Minister Gen Nakatani responded that the Air Self Defense Force had never encountered such objects. Inoki, known for his diverse career and political stunts, also claimed to have seen a UFO but acknowledged uncertainty about the existence of aliens. This exchange reflects ongoing interest in the topic among Japanese politicians, with previous discussions touching on the legal implications of an extraterrestrial invasion under Japan's pacifist constitution.

A 35-year-old passenger named Jin Pai was hospitalized after breaking a toilet at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in Hefei, China, while squatting on its rim due to hygiene concerns. The toilet collapsed, causing deep cuts to his leg and buttocks. He initially called for help from his traveling companions but was too embarrassed to seek assistance directly. Emergency services treated him with several dozen stitches. Jin Pai later claimed he was sitting when the toilet broke, potentially to avoid paying compensation. Authorities stated the incident was accidental and advised against standing on toilets.

A 56-year-old man named Kevin Rebbie from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested after a 15-year-old girl discovered a hidden camera in her bathroom that police traced back to him. The investigation revealed that Rebbie had sexually abused the girl and others over a four-year period, filming them without consent. He faced multiple charges including aggravated indecent assault and invasion of privacy. The camera captured 41 videos, mostly of the girl and others showering, and some showing close-up images of genitalia. Rebbie admitted to filming several victims, primarily targeting the now-15-year-old girl. His preliminary hearing was scheduled for May 1st, and he was held on a $500,000 bail.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama captures a series of images where teenage daughters stand po-faced next to their fathers, who are leaping into the air. These photographs are part of a book titled "Daughter and Salary Man," highlighting the contrast between the serious demeanor of fathers typically expected in family portraits and their playful, heroic poses. The fathers are dressed in sharp suits, and the daughters wear casual clothing. The images are taken in front of various Japanese landmarks and aim to showcase the father's fun side, though some older fathers appear slightly pained during the leaps. These unique portraits have gained significant online interest due to their curious nature.

The passage discusses the return of Kevin Pietersen to Surrey ahead of the county championship season, following the dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director. Pietersen, who was controversially removed from the England team in 2014, is seen posing for a team photo with a mix of deep thought and joviality. He jokes with photographers and team members, indicating his potential return to the international set-up as England aims to reclaim the Ashes urn in the upcoming home series.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a Romanian football club facing relegation, has fired Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. Ze Maria was initially reinstated but was fired again after a loss to FC Botosani. He had previously replaced Florin Marin in January and was Ceahlaul's third coach of the season. The club will now be managed by Serbian coach Vanya Radinovic.

Nabil Dirar, a former teammate of Radamel Falcao at Monaco, believes Falcao is regretting his loan move to Manchester United. Falcao, who was not happy in France, has struggled to perform since joining United on loan last summer, scoring only four goals and failing to match his pre-injury form. United would need to pay £46 million to make the transfer permanent, but they are unlikely to exercise this option due to his poor performance. Dirar suggests Falcao might have been better off staying at Monaco, where he could have played in the Champions League and benefited from a more supportive environment.

A tall man wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluorescent orange sweatshirt robbed a dairy in Christchurch, taking the till and around $1500 in cash. The incident occurred on Saturday when the owner's daughter reported a masked man demanding money. No weapons were used, but the mask made the robbery more frightening. Police are seeking public assistance to identify the suspect and have provided contact details for those with information.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested twice for alleged sexual misconduct with minor students. Initially, she was arrested on March 19 for having an inappropriate relationship with a 15-year-old student, during which she admitted to kissing and allowing the student to touch her breasts. She was released on bail and subsequently suspended from teaching. Days later, another 15-year-old student accused Granado of having sex with him on two consecutive nights in January in her car. Granado was arrested again on March 24 and was released after posting a $50,000 bail. School officials stated that she was placed on administrative leave to prevent her from working with students or being on school property.

A video showing a crocodile swimming through a public marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog in its mouth has gone viral, being viewed over half a million times. The incident occurred during a holiday for New Zealander Tim Weston, who witnessed the crocodile holding onto the dog for hours. The dog belonged to the owner of a local bike shop and was reportedly curious about the crocodile near the water's edge. Weston mentioned that there is a nearby sanctuary for crocodiles, and the animal was likely from there. Social media reactions were predominantly negative, with some users expressing fear or disgust towards crocodiles.

Steve Bruce remains confident in his ability to keep Hull City in the Barclays Premier League despite a recent 2-0 loss to Southampton. Hull City currently sits just two points above the relegation zone and has six games left in the season, including matches against strong opponents like Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. Bruce attributes their struggles to several long-term injuries to key players, though he maintains optimism about securing a positive outcome. The loss to Southampton included a penalty from James Ward-Prowse and a late goal from Graziano Pelle. Ronald Koeman, the manager of Southampton, addressed an incident where Sadio Mane attempted to take a penalty instead of Ward-Prowse, the designated taker.

A teacher named Ian Guffick was banned from teaching for at least two years after altering SATs exam answers for pupils at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire. Despite the exam session having ended, Guffick allowed students to change their answers and even altered some himself. This led to the annulment of the entire school's SATs results due to a breach of exam rules. While Guffick claimed he only wanted to improve answer legibility, the panel ruled that no changes should be made to exam scripts outside of test conditions. He admitted to the allegations and accepted it as unacceptable professional conduct.

Anders Lindegaard, a goalkeeper for Manchester United, has had limited playing time but enjoys a happy personal life with his wife Misse Beqiri. They were married in a beach wedding in Mauritius and have a son together. Lindegaard, who has struggled to secure regular playing time since joining Manchester United in 2010, often posts about his relationship on social media. His wife, a Swedish model with Albanian roots, frequently shares her modeling photos on Instagram. Despite his challenges on the field, Lindegaard appears to be thriving in his personal life.

The 13 glowing blue letters that illuminated Yankee Stadium in the Bronx since 1976 were put up for auction at Sotheby's but failed to sell, with the highest bid being $260,000 from a Sotheby's employee. The current owner, Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, purchased the letters in 2008 and hoped they would be acquired by someone in the U.S. to enjoy them. The letters were expected to fetch between $300,000 and $600,000. Additionally, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 1960s sold for $112,500, exceeding its estimate.

Brendan Rodgers, Liverpool's manager, spoke to Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their professional responsibilities after incidents involving illegal substances and smoking. Despite these issues, Rodgers decided not to discipline the players and instead focused on moving forward. He emphasized the importance of understanding what professionals can and cannot do. Rodgers also mentioned that Steven Gerrard, who recently returned from a suspension, could potentially play in the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa. Rodgers expressed that while it is painful to fall short in competitions, it is important to use those experiences to improve and eventually succeed.

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal's playmaker, returned to London after the international break and shared a picture of himself relaxing with his dog, captioned "Home Sweet Home." Despite missing Arsenal's previous match due to illness, Ozil performed well in Germany's Euro 2016 qualifier against Georgia. He is expected to start in the upcoming Premier League match against Liverpool. Ozil has been in good form since returning from injury, contributing with four assists and three goals since January. He also mentioned that he enjoys the demanding schedule of playing many matches in quick succession, which suits his style of play.

Barcelona's president, Josep Maria Bartomeu, has stated that the club has no intention of replacing Luis Enrique as their coach, despite rumors suggesting otherwise. Enrique, who took over as coach last summer, is currently leading Barcelona towards winning La Liga and has a contract until 2016. Bartomeu expressed satisfaction with Enrique's performance and noted that the team remains competitive in multiple competitions.

Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract with Liverpool, which will run until 2020 and is estimated to be worth around £100,000 per week. This comes after discussions between Henderson's advisors and Liverpool since the start of the season. Henderson, 24, is the third significant player in Brendan Rodgers' squad to extend their contract, following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. The deal is seen as a boost for Liverpool, especially considering Henderson's improved performance under Rodgers and his potential future role as club captain when Steven Gerrard leaves.

Filipe Luis, who signed a three-year contract with Chelsea last July, insists he wants to stay at the club until the end of his contract, despite Atletico Madrid considering re-signing him. Luis has struggled to establish himself as the left-back at Chelsea but remains happy with the team. During the international break, he played for Brazil in friendly matches. Chelsea's manager, Jose Mourinho, emphasizes the need for focus and winning every remaining match in the Premier League title run-in. Luis acknowledges the difficulty of the upcoming nine games but believes the team is well-prepared.

Nathan Hughes, a forward for Wasps, had his ban overturned after accidentally knocking out George North during a match. Initially suspended for three matches due to being deemed "reckless," Hughes was later cleared of the ban following an appeal. The incident involved Hughes' knee colliding with North's head, causing North to become unconscious and requiring medical attention. Despite no intent to harm, Hughes was initially banned and missed crucial matches. The appeal was supported by Wasps and other rugby figures who criticized the initial decision. Hughes is now free to play immediately, though he will likely wait until April 26 to make his return.

The passage describes how wildfires in southeastern Siberia caused by farmers led to dramatic sunsets in Washington and other parts of the Pacific Northwest. The fires spread rapidly due to strong winds, destroying numerous villages. Smoke from these fires was carried across the Pacific Ocean by atmospheric winds, affecting areas like Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. This smoke filtered out shorter wavelengths of sunlight, resulting in intense red and orange sunsets. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve, and the sunsets will return to normal.

Becky Schoenig, a mother from St. Louis, Missouri, had her brand new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway. About a month later, the car was returned to her, but with new red rims, red detailing, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Instead of being upset, Schoenig thanked the "car thieves" for "pimping out" her vehicle and posted about it on Facebook. She is now getting the car professionally cleaned due to a strong smell of cigarettes and marijuana and is creating a smoothie called "Sexton on Wheels" to honor Mick Sexton, who found her car.

Manchester City players risk losing significant bonuses if the team fails to qualify for the Champions League this season. Star players like Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart, and Yaya Toure are on incentivized contracts to ensure compliance with financial fairplay rules. Currently, City is in fourth place, needing to avoid finishing fifth to secure a spot in the Champions League. If they miss out, the entire squad stands to lose about £12 million in bonuses. Manager Manuel Pellegrini acknowledges the team's poor performance and the need for improvement. Meanwhile, Manchester United's victory over Manchester City has put them in a stronger position to attract top talent, including Paul Pogba.

The passage describes a youth football match between Manchester United's Under 18s and Manchester City's Under 18s, which United won 1-0. The match took place at Altrincham's compact stadium, with a focus on providing a realistic experience for the young players. Manchester United's Callum Gribbin scored the only goal with a free-kick, while Manchester City had several chances but failed to score. The match highlighted the local talent in Manchester and raised hopes for future opportunities for these young players in senior teams.

Joe Hart, who achieved his 50th cap for England, praised Gianluigi Buffon, who reached his 147th cap, calling him a "legend of the game." Hart expressed admiration for Buffon's continued excellence at 37 and mentioned his own aspirations to continue improving and contributing to the national team. Both goalkeepers showed pride in their achievements, with Hart emphasizing his desire to reach more caps for both club and country.

Chipotle, a Mexican restaurant chain, has entered the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with Postmates to offer delivery services in 67 cities. This move comes with a 9% service charge and varying delivery fees based on distance and demand. Previously, Chipotle had declined other delivery service offers but has now accepted Postmates. Other major chains like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also expanding their delivery services through partnerships or new programs. Notably, both presidential candidates, Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton, have been observed dining at Chipotle locations.

The parents of Martin Richard, an 8-year-old victim of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, are pleading with the Justice Department to remove the death penalty option for the convicted bomber, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. In a Boston Globe op-ed, Bill and Denise Richard describe the emotional toll of losing their son and enduring the trial process. They advocate for a life sentence without parole, arguing that pursuing the death penalty would lead to prolonged appeals and continuous reminders of their loss. The Richards emphasize that they are speaking on behalf of their family and hope to move forward, focusing on rebuilding their lives and supporting their surviving children.

A custom-built Boeing 747 has been transformed into a luxury private jet home for a mystery billionaire, costing approximately £400 million. The aircraft, designed to accommodate a single wealthy owner and numerous guests, features multiple rooms including a dining area, lounge, bedrooms, and a conference room. The interior mimics a luxury hotel with plush furnishings and amenities such as a private chef and entertainment areas. The plane, originally capable of carrying up to 600 passengers, now offers a unique and extravagant travel experience.

SpaceX launched an uncrewed cargo spacecraft, Dragon, on a Falcon 9 rocket from Cape Canaveral to the International Space Station. The primary mission was successful, but SpaceX failed in its attempt to land the rocket stage on a floating barge. The rocket landed but tipped over. This was SpaceX's sixth mission to the International Space Station and the first attempt to land a Falcon 9 rocket on a drone ship, which SpaceX plans to continue attempting to reduce the cost of space access. The Dragon will deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies, including research equipment and an espresso machine, and return with over 3,000 pounds of cargo after about five weeks.

Priscilla Presley will serve as a witness at the first wedding to be held at a newly opened Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas. The chapel, located inside the Westgate Hotel, is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit of Elvis Presley's artifacts outside his home in Memphis. A contest run by NBC's Today show will determine which Elvis-obsessed couple wins the 'ultimate wedding' package, including a ceremony at the chapel, a reception, hotel stay, and tickets to an Elvis show. Priscilla emphasized that no impersonators will be allowed and that the event is serious.

Jordan Henderson believes Liverpool can catch Manchester City in the Premier League after a strong performance and recent winning form. Both Henderson and Simon Mignolet achieved the record for most appearances in top five European leagues this season. Liverpool won 2-0 against Newcastle United, with goals from Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen. Despite being four points behind City, Henderson encourages the team to continue performing well to close the gap.

Roma ended their four-month winless streak at home by defeating Napoli in a crucial Serie A match. Miralem Pjanic scored the only goal in the 25th minute through a counter-attack, with goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis making several saves in the second half. This victory moved Roma provisionally four points ahead of city rivals Lazio. The match was tense due to security concerns following a fan fatality in a previous incident. Despite having a strong performance, Napoli could not secure a win, extending their winless streak to five matches.

The passage describes an uneventful football match between Doncaster Rovers and Fleetwood Town in League One, resulting in a 0-0 draw. Due to the lack of action, Doncaster's media team created a short highlight video, only 27 seconds long, featuring just the opening kickoff, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

A man named Roland Giroux has filmed his blood parrot cichlid fish receiving gentle strokes and massages from his hand inside the fish tank. The fish initially reacts by moving away but gradually becomes more relaxed and even follows the man to the surface of the water. Giroux explains that he had to remove two other fish from the tank due to their bullying behavior towards the blood parrot cichlid. Over time, he trained the fish to enjoy human interaction, noting that it gets frustrated if not played with daily. The fish, which is a hybrid of midas and redheaded cichlids, enjoys being stroked and spends at least 15 minutes each day in close contact with the man.

The passage discusses Ben Stokes' role and management within the England cricket team. Stokes is known for his fiery character and aggressive playing style, which has both brought excitement to the team and required careful handling. After a clash with Marlon Samuels, England coach Peter Moores had a conversation with Stokes to guide his behavior. The team aims to balance Stokes' natural exuberance with controlled aggression, ensuring he continues to contribute effectively through runs and wickets without becoming pigeonholed. England plans to include Stokes in the team as much as possible to help him reach his full potential, while also considering the strategic use of other players like Adil Rashid and Chris Jordan.

The passage discusses a highly anticipated Euro 2016 qualifier match between Wales and Belgium set to take place at Cardiff City Stadium on June 12. This match has sold out with 33,000 tickets sold, driven by high expectations after Wales' recent 3-0 victory over Israel. Despite Belgium's higher world ranking, both teams currently have 11 points, with Belgium leading due to better goal difference. The match is significant as it could secure one of the two automatic qualifying spots for the 2016 finals in France. The Football Association of Wales has noted the strong demand for tickets. Interestingly, while there was initial speculation about playing at the larger Millennium Stadium, UEFA rules prevented this change, and the Wales squad prefers the more intimate Cardiff City Stadium.

The passage provides details about the England Under-17 national football team's squad for the upcoming UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria. Key points include:

- The team is the defending champions.
- They are in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland.
- Notable inclusions are Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, as well as Arsenal's Chris Willock making his debut.
- Matches are scheduled against Italy, Holland, and Ireland.
- The squad consists of goalkeepers, defenders, midfielders, and forwards from various Premier League clubs.

Manchester City are interested in signing Evangelos Patoulidis, a 14-year-old playmaker from Anderlecht's youth system, who has also drawn interest from Arsenal and Barcelona. Patoulidis chose to stay at Anderlecht over Barcelona's offer due to family wishes for him to continue his education. City have discussed potential compensation with Anderlecht's chairman and are aiming to secure Patoulidis to build for the future under Manuel Pellegrini.

A 33-year-old transgender escort named Vanessa Santillan was found strangled and beaten to death in a £400,000 flat in Fulham, London, in late March. She had been working as an escort in London, Paris, and Miami. A 23-year-old man has been arrested in connection with her death but has been bailed, with further questioning scheduled. Police are appealing to anyone who may have interacted with Miss Santillan in the hours before her death and are seeking information to solve the case.

A woman named Dawn, who experienced seven miscarriages and lost a baby named Daniel James, was devastated to find that her friend Jamie, who lived with her and her partner, had stolen £207 intended for Daniel's grave stone. During an appearance on The Jeremy Kyle Show, Dawn suspected Jamie and his girlfriend Carol of the theft. After a lie detector test confirmed Jamie's guilt, Dawn broke down in tears and left the show. Jamie had previously admitted to taking the money via a Facebook message but blamed it on Carol. Dawn expressed feeling betrayed and emphasized the emotional significance of the money for their loss.

The passage describes the release of over 200 Yazidis by ISIS, primarily women and children, facilitated by Arab tribal leaders. The Yazidis, a minority group persecuted by ISIS, were previously displaced and subjected to violence, including killings, enslavement, and rape. The release comes amid ongoing conflicts and humanitarian crises in northern Iraq, where ISIS conquered several Yazidi towns, leading to significant displacement and suffering. The international community responded with aid drops and airstrikes against ISIS.

Harry Kane, a standout player for Tottenham and part of the England national team, is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season. He is featured in a new animated video by Copa90 that showcases some of his best goals and celebrations from the season. The video, titled "Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?", highlights his long-range strike against Chelsea, a headed goal against Arsenal, and his debut goal for England. Kane faces competition from players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez for the PFA Player of the Year award at an upcoming ceremony.

Jamie Carragher supports Brendan Rodgers as Liverpool's manager despite the team's recent struggles, including missing out on the top four and being eliminated from the FA Cup. Carragher believes Rodgers' future shouldn't be determined by one season and thinks improvements are needed in the squad. He also mentions his own community work through the 23 Foundation, aiming to inspire young people from underprivileged areas.

A four-year-old boy named James Hayward had his toy Nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport due to it being deemed a security risk. Airport security frisked James and demanded he surrender the plastic toy, which fires sponge darts. James' father, Phil Hayward, found the security measures excessive and criticized the staff's reaction. Upon returning from their holiday in Lanzarote, James received a replacement toy gun. The airport apologized for the inconvenience but adhered to security regulations prohibiting items that resemble prohibited items.

A 31-year-old man from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. He listed numerous requirements for his ideal partner, including being non-drinker and non-smoker, fit and attractive, reliable, honest, and loyal. The man, identified only as "Rich," also offered various perks such as accommodation, a company car, phone, and laptop. He emphasized the importance of enjoying outdoor activities while also being a "princess when needed." Rich highlighted his own attributes, such as being athletic, tattooed, and independent, and expressed willingness to spend money on his partner. He invited all reasonable offers and specified that former partners were not welcome.

Greg Dyke, the Football Association chairman, is supported by five former England managers in his push for radical changes to improve the development of home-grown players. These changes include increasing the minimum number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to twelve and redefining 'home-grown' to mean players who have trained in England for three years before turning 18. The former managers, including Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren, warn that failing to support these proposals could harm the English game and hinder the country's chances of winning the World Cup. They argue that the current pool of English talent at the highest level is shrinking, which is a disadvantage for England's national team. Despite recent positive performances in qualifiers, the managers emphasize the need for more opportunities for young English players like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane to develop and compete at the top level.

The passage discusses the upcoming episode of the TV show Poldark, where Ross Poldark (Aidan Turner) will be seen with his newborn daughter Demelza Poldark (Eleanor Tomlinson). The pregnancy is portrayed as moving very quickly, with Demelza going from barely showing to eight months pregnant within a short period, and then giving birth just minutes later. Fans have noted this rapid progression and commented on it, comparing it to previous quick pregnancies in the show.

Leicester City's manager, Nigel Pearson, advises his team to stay focused on their upcoming matches rather than worrying about their relegation rivals. After securing back-to-back wins, including a late victory over West Bromwich Albion, Leicester remains at the bottom of the Premier League table but is now three points away from safety. Pearson emphasizes that the team's fate is in their own hands and encourages them to concentrate on their own performance in the remaining matches. He also notes that while positive results are beneficial, they only matter if the team performs well in their own games.

The passage describes how a North Pacific gray whale named Varvara completed the longest known migration by a mammal, swimming approximately 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico, via the Pacific Ocean and the West Coast of the United States. This journey surpasses the previous record held by a humpback whale. Varvara's extensive travels, including visits to three major breeding areas, suggest she may be an eastern gray whale rather than a western one, as previously thought. This discovery could imply that the two types of gray whales are not as genetically distinct as once believed, with only around 150 western gray whales currently existing.

Residents on the Shiretoko Peninsula in Hokkaido, Japan, were surprised to find a new stretch of coastline emerge overnight, with parts rising up to 50 feet above sea level. This sudden change is attributed to a landslide triggered by melting ice and snow, causing a section of the seabed to rise. The newly emerged landmass is approximately 1,000-1,640 feet long and 100 feet wide. Locals did not notice any signs of movement or feel tremors, and authorities do not expect the land to expand further.

Gregory van der Wiel, a full back for Paris Saint-Germain, has denied rumors of his potential departure from the club. He recently had a disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc but maintains his love for the team and city. Van der Wiel expresses his desire to sign a new contract and is prepared to play whenever called upon. Despite this, Paris Saint-Germain is also linked with Barcelona's Dani Alves, suggesting that Van der Wiel may have limited choice in staying with the club.

Carlos Tevez, a 31-year-old striker, has expressed a desire to terminate his contract with Juventus early to return to his former club, Boca Juniors, in Argentina. Despite being under contract until the end of next season, Tevez is close to completing his return to Boca Juniors, according to the club's president, Daniel Angelici. Tevez is currently performing well for Juventus, having scored 17 goals in the current season and contributing to their potential Serie A title win. However, Juventus are considering potential replacements due to Tevez's unexpected request to leave. Tevez's international manager, Tata Martino, supports his decision and believes it won't affect Tevez's future with the national team.

Pep Guardiola, manager of Bayern Munich, tore a hole in his trouser leg during a 6-1 Champions League victory over Porto at the Allianz Arena. Despite the wardrobe malfunction, Bayern secured their place in the semi-finals with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and a brace from Robert Lewandowski. Porto entered the match with a two-goal advantage from the first leg but were thoroughly outplayed by Bayern.

A multi-vehicle crash involving ten people, including four children, occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale, in Brisbane's west. Three vehicles collided, resulting in several injuries. Three individuals, including a 40-year-old man and a five-year-old boy, were flown to Princess Alexandra Hospital with serious injuries. Another 27-year-old woman and a six-year-old girl were also airlifted to the same hospital. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for further assessment. A man sustained hand lacerations, while two females escaped injury. Emergency crews freed one trapped individual using hydraulic cutting gear, and the affected section of the highway was closed with diversions in place.

The passage discusses upcoming Premier League match between Arsenal and Chelsea, focusing on Arsenal midfielder Mesut Ozil's excitement about receiving a new Apple Watch. Ozil shared his joy on Instagram by comparing the watch to the one worn by the TV character Michael Knight from Knight Rider. Additionally, the passage mentions that Arsenal is trailing Chelsea by 10 points with six league games remaining, and highlights the return of Jack Wilshere to the team after a five-month injury absence. Club legend Ray Parlour expresses confidence in Wilshere's potential but raises concerns about his ability to stay fit consistently.

Referee Mark Clattenburg has been assigned to officiate the Manchester derby between Manchester United and Manchester City at Old Trafford. Despite sending off three players from both teams this season, Clattenburg has only issued two red cards to United players. Vincent Kompany, the City captain, is suspended due to a red card received during an international match. The match is significant as Manchester United is now a point ahead of Manchester City, adding extra motivation for both teams. Clattenburg will be assisted by Simon Beck, Jake Collin, and Jonathan Moss.

MP Bob Katter accused the Queensland Government of assuming that Billy Gordon, an embattled MP, would resign after accusations of domestic violence and failure to disclose his criminal history. Katter, who is of Lebanese descent, used the term "little black puppet on a string," drawing criticism for its terminology. Gordon, a former Queensland Labor Party member, quit the party and remains in the parliament as an independent, causing political turmoil for the government. Katter defended his statement, explaining that he used the term based on his personal experiences with racism.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Illinois born with cerebral palsy, creates dance videos to inspire others and challenge stereotypes about disabilities. She aims to show that despite facing bullying and stares, she is capable and similar to her peers. Dayna uses her platform to promote positivity and encourage people to look beyond her condition. She has given motivational talks at local schools and continues to use her experiences to inspire others.

Orlando City, an MLS team coached by Adrian Heath, has shown interest in signing Javier Hernandez from Manchester United. Hernandez, a Mexican player who had a difficult loan period at Real Madrid, could be a significant commercial asset due to Orlando's large Latin-American fanbase. Despite interest from eight European clubs, including Wolfsburg, AC Milan, and Inter Milan, Orlando City remains a contender. Additionally, Manchester United has offered a revised contract to teenage midfielder Andreas Pereira, whose father has received interest from several European clubs such as Paris Saint-Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord.

A group of at least three people poured gasoline on a white Dodge Charger at a 76 Station in South Los Angeles and set it on fire around 12:15 am on Saturday. This occurred after the driver had an argument with the suspects, who attempted to carjack him. The suspects used a gun during the attempt. Two passengers were inside the car at the time, but no one was injured. The car's front end was completely destroyed. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson, and surveillance video is being used in the investigation.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor from Lamoni, Iowa, has surrendered his state license after admitting to misconduct including accepting sex as payment and performing exorcisms on patients. Despite receiving positive patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com, he agreed not to seek reinstatement for at least 10 years. The agreement stipulates that he must demonstrate that the circumstances leading to his license revocation no longer exist before he can practice again.

The passage describes a recent incident where a Russian SU-27 fighter jet intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane in international airspace north of Poland in an "unsafe and unprofessional" manner, according to the U.S. Pentagon. The U.S. claims the Russian pilot performed aggressive maneuvers near their aircraft at high speeds. There is a dispute regarding whether the U.S. plane had its transponder on or off. In response, the U.S. plans to file a diplomatic complaint with Russia. This is not the first such incident; a similar close encounter occurred a year ago over the Sea of Okhotsk. Both countries' aircraft frequently interact in various regions including Northern Europe and the area between Russia and Alaska.

A sniper rifle belonging to an FBI agent was stolen from the window of his car in a Salt Lake City hotel parking lot. This occurred just days before President Obama's visit to Utah. The rifle was secured in a hard case and attached to a truck safe with padlocks and chains. However, it was taken when the thief broke the car window, used a rope to detach the case, and utilized another vehicle's momentum to free the case. The theft also resulted in the loss of the agent's gear bag, backpack, and personal items. The case handle was broken off, and the rifle has not been recovered. The incident took place at the Marriott Springhill Suites, located near the airport and close to the FBI office.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of murdering his elderly neighbor, Terrence Freebody, in July 2012. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen examined Costa and concluded that his declining mental state due to dementia and alcohol abuse may have contributed to the crime. Costa's behavior during and after the incident, including fluctuating moods and signs of confusion, supported this conclusion. The case hinges on proving Costa's unstable mental state at the time of the attack, as this could result in a not guilty verdict.

The passage describes an incident where Ross Barkley took a penalty kick for Everton against Burnley instead of Leighton Baines, who has a high success rate with penalties. Despite no dispute between the teammates, this decision recalls a previous penalty mishap. Manager Roberto Martinez defended Barkley's choice, stating that he is comfortable with multiple players taking penalties and that Barkley handled the responsibility well. However, Barkley's shot was saved by Burnley's goalkeeper, Tom Heaton, though Everton still won the match 1-0 with a goal from Mirallas.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on the ms Ryndam cruise ship while it was docked in San Juan, Puerto Rico. Holland America Line reported that the incident appears to be a murder-suicide, though the official cause is yet to be determined by authorities, who include the FBI. The ship had departed from Tampa, Florida, on a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise. The discovery was made by the cleaning staff when they knocked on the cabin door.

Patrick Kluivert, a former Dutch forward and assistant coach, has led Curacao to a successful start in World Cup qualifying. Curacao advanced to the second qualifying round in CONCACAF for the 2018 World Cup after winning a 4-3 aggregate against Montserrat. They secured this advancement through a 2-1 victory in Willemstad and a 2-2 draw in Montserrat. Kluivert, whose mother is from Curacao, will face Cuba in the next round on June 8 and 16.

Esteban Cambiasso, known for his numerous major European titles, believes that helping Leicester City stay in the Premier League is as significant as winning a trophy. Currently seven points from safety with eight games left, Cambiasso remains optimistic and committed to the team's objective. He emphasizes that his experience and dedication will contribute to their chances of avoiding relegation. Despite not winning a match since January, Cambiasso is confident in his teammates and the team's potential to secure their Premier League status.

A 23-year-old mother, Gemma, risks losing access to her two young children due to her ongoing issues with drinking, partying, and suspected theft. Her 52-year-old mother, Debbie, has been caring for the children since Gemma was unable to look after them properly. Debbie is considering banning Gemma from seeing the children altogether, citing concerns about Gemma's behavior and past theft. Gemma admits to past thefts but denies stealing an iPad from one of the children. Debbie, who has cared for the children since birth, feels Gemma does not prioritize their well-being and is preparing to cut ties due to her daughter's lifestyle choices.

The passage describes a goal scored by Eden Hazard for Chelsea against Manchester United at Stamford Bridge. During the build-up to the goal, John Terry made a strong challenge on Radamel Falcao, which the pundits believed was a foul. The incident led to a loose ball that Cesc Fabregas collected and passed to Oscar, who then set up Hazard for the goal. Despite the successful goal, the pundits, including Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness, agreed that Terry's tackle on Falcao should have resulted in a foul being called.

A tour bus belonging to Lady Antebellum caught fire on a Texas freeway, but all passengers were safely evacuated. Hillary Scott, the band's co-lead singer, posted about the incident on Instagram, noting that the fire destroyed most items in the bus's back lounge except her Bible. The bus likely caught fire after a rear tire blew out and the bus stopped. Michael Barnett captured dramatic video of the event. The band members scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards were not on the bus at the time.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman, a physicist from Dundee University, proposes using space lasers to generate solar power for homes, aiming to make solar power viable even in places like Scotland. His concept involves satellites orbiting Earth, equipped with mirrors to capture sunlight and convert it into laser light, which is then directed back to Earth to power solar panels. While the lasers won't be as powerful as those depicted in movies, they could provide instant power restoration to disaster-stricken areas. Dr. Quarterman plans to conduct further trials in Portugal after initial success in Scotland. Additionally, the passage mentions a separate proposal by Japanese researchers to use lasers on the International Space Station to address space debris, though these lasers would also not be powerful enough for weaponization.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted pedophile with a "fanatical obsession" towards young girls, went missing after vanishing from a psychiatric unit. Last seen leaving a hospital near Hook, Hampshire, Munden is described as 5ft 8ins tall, heavy-built, and having dark hair. He was previously detained under the Mental Health Act for sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus. Munden, who also possesses indecent images of children and has learning difficulties, is the subject of a manhunt.

A Los Angeles judge ordered V. Stiviano to pay back over $2.6 million in gifts from Donald Sterling to her, as part of a lawsuit filed by Sterling's wife, Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling. The gifts included expensive vehicles and a property, which Stiviano denied taking advantage of. The ruling is seen as a victory for the Sterling family and sets a precedent allowing the injured spouse to recover damages from the recipient of such gifts.

Thierry Henry, speaking as a pundit on Sky Sports, criticized Arsenal's recent transfer activities and suggested they need to acquire four top players—goalkeeper, center back, defensive midfielder, and striker—to have a chance at winning the Barclays Premier League. He specifically mentioned Arsenal's current position and their upcoming matches. Henry also questioned Arsenal's ability to win the league with Olivier Giroud as the primary striker, despite Giroud's 14 league goals, suggesting they might need to replace him.

A young woman, a victim of years of abuse by Maurice Van Ryn, the boss of Bega Cheese, testified in Sydney's District Court about the severe impact of his actions on her life. Van Ryn, a wealthy New South Wales businessman, has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offenses, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim expressed fear for her future relationships and explained that she did not understand why she was targeted or that what Van Ryn did was wrong at the time. She only spoke out after learning of his arrest and has since struggled with depression and self-harm.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is recovering from a serious knee injury that kept him out since March 2014. He recently played 90 minutes for Arsenal's Under 21 team and is optimistic about his recovery, stating he feels "better and better." Gnabry previously impressed for the first team last season before his injury. He is now looking forward to his next match.

A young accountant named Jacob Phillips, 23, fell to his death after running from a taxi driver in Penarth, South Wales, in December. Phillips, who had been out drinking with friends, attempted to avoid paying the fare and ran from the driver, who chased him. In the dark, Phillips leapt over a fence and fell 70 feet down a cliff. His body was discovered the next day by a dog walker on a rocky beach. The coroner recorded an accidental death verdict, noting Phillips likely became disoriented and did not realize the danger. Phillips worked for Pretty Green and had recently returned to Wales for Christmas.

The passage describes a significant issue with passport delays affecting thousands of holidaymakers in the previous summer. Despite the passport office making a substantial profit of £42 million, many affected individuals did not receive compensation. The Home Affairs Committee chairman, Keith Vaz, expressed astonishment at the low number of compensation approvals (only 2,191 out of thousands of applications) and criticized the lack of refunds for those who missed trips or paid extra for expedited services. Additionally, the article highlights that managers received bonuses while customers faced financial losses and inconvenience.

The passage describes a unique home in Horfield, Bristol, that has remained largely unchanged since the 1930s. Key features include original stained-glass windows, an oil-fired central heating system, and retro kitchen and bathroom fixtures. The property, listed for sale between £200,000 and £250,000, offers a collector's paradise with original bathrooms, kitchens, and cupboards. Inside, there are quirky elements such as wood-panelled hallways and living room windows adorned with coats of arms. Despite some modern upgrades, the house retains many old-fashioned features that are now considered nostalgic.

Colin Kaepernick became the starting quarterback for the 49ers mid-2012 season after Alex Smith got a concussion and led the team to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, though they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
The passage describes Soul Food, a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

The passage provides biographical information about Anne Rice, including her birthplace in New Orleans and subsequent moves to Texas and San Francisco. It also describes Route 495, a 3.45 mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, which connects the New Jersey Turnpike to New York State Route 495 inside the Lincoln Tunnel, offering access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language television network owned by Comcast via NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

The passage provides a concise summary of Damon Albarn's early life, his formation of the band Blur, and his solo career. Key points include:
- Albarn grew up in Leytonstone and Colchester.
- He attended Stanway School and met Graham Coxon there, forming Blur.
- Blur's debut album "Leisure" was released in 1991.
- Blur's self-titled album from 2001 was a worldwide success.
- Albarn's debut solo album "Everyday Robots" came out in 2014.
- The solo album featured collaborations and unique elements like sampling Lord Buckley.

Mogadishu, also known as Muqdisho or Hamar, is the capital and largest city of Somalia. It serves as the location for numerous significant national institutions due to its status as the country's capital.
The passage describes "Happiness in Slavery," a song by the American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails, which is from their debut extended play, Broken, released in 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born on August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter who has been nominated for a BAFTA award.

The passage describes two media works featuring Bob Lee Swagger as the main character. In the 2007 film "Shooter," Swagger, played by Mark Wahlberg, is framed for murder by a rogue private military company. In the TV series "Shooter," starring Ryan Phillippe, Swagger, an expert marksman in exile, is persuaded to return to action upon discovering a plan to assassinate the president.
House, M.D., is an American television medical drama that aired on Fox for eight seasons from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was found guilty of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate, and two others. These killings were carried out by Manson's followers as instructed by him. Following these charges, commercial recordings of songs written and performed by Manson were released.

Sean Justin Penn, born on August 17, 1960, is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist. He began his acting career in 1974 with a TV appearance and had his film debut in 1981. Penn gained critical recognition in the 1980s through various roles in crime dramas and became a prominent leading actor after his performance in "Dead Man Walking" in 1995, where he received his first Academy Award nomination. He won his first Academy Award for Best Actor in 2003 for "Mystic River" and a second one in 2008 for "Milk."

Don Bradman, born on August 27, 1908, and passed away on February 25, 2001, was an Australian cricketer renowned as one of the greatest batsmen ever. After retiring from playing, he maintained his influence in cricket through roles as an administrator, selector, and writer for over three decades.

L.A. Reid has held senior leadership positions at several major record labels, including serving as chairman and CEO of Epic Records, president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is a drummer who has played in several notable rock bands including Rage Against the Machine, Audioslave, and Prophets of Rage. He co-founded Rage Against the Machine in 1991 and has been involved with various projects since then. The passage also mentions that Rage is a German heavy metal band formed in 1984 by Peter "Peavy" Wagner, though this information is not directly related to Wilk's career.

The multi-camera series "The Millers" aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015, spanning two seasons with a total of 34 episodes. The show was cancelled by CBS on November 14, 2014, during its second season.

The passage provides information about Dorothy Ann Willis Richards, who served as the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995. She was a Democrat and the second female governor of Texas, known for her feminism and memorable quotes. Richards gained national recognition as the state treasurer of Texas when she gave the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. She lost her bid for re-election in 1994 to George W. Bush. The passage also mentions that Ann Richards, likely Dorothy's mother or another individual with the same name, was an American jazz singer married to pianist Stan Kenton, who lived from October 1, 1935, to April 1, 1982.
Drake Bell released an independent EP titled "A Reminder" in 2011.

The passage provides information about the 1979 American drama film "Boardwalk" written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman and directed by Verona. It also includes details about Janet Leigh, an American actress, singer, dancer, and author who was born on July 6, 1927, and passed away on October 3, 2004. Additionally, it mentions that she wrote four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels.

The passage describes Simón Bolívar, born on July 24, 1783, and died on December 17, 1830, who is known as "El Libertador." He was a key military and political leader in establishing Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama as independent nations from Spanish rule.

The Bermuda Triangle, also referred to as the Devil's Triangle, is an area in the western North Atlantic Ocean where numerous aircraft and ships are claimed to have vanished under unexplained conditions.

Colin Kaepernick became the starting quarterback for the 49ers mid-2012 season after Alex Smith's concussion and led them to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994. In his first full season as starter in 2013, he guided the 49ers to the NFC Championship.
The passage describes Marnie as a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is a form of marketing communication that uses openly sponsored, non-personal messages to promote products, services, or ideas. It differs from personal selling by being non-personal and is disseminated via various media, both traditional like newspapers, TV, and radio, and modern such as websites and text messages.

The passage provides two pieces of information about "Private Lives": it is a 1930 comedy of manners play by Noël Coward in three acts, and it is also a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.
Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton, was a British Conservative politician and statesman who served as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1957 to 1963.

Aristotle, born in 384 BC in Stagira, Chalkidice, was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist. He studied under Plato at the Academy in Athens from ages 17-37. After Plato's death, Aristotle tutored Alexander the Great from 343 BC onwards at the request of Philip II of Macedon.

David Mordechai Packouz, born on February 16, 1982, is an American who has worked as an arms dealer, musician, inventor, and entrepreneur. He invented the BeatBuddy guitar pedal drum machine and is currently the CEO of Singular Sound, a music technology company.

Magic Johnson played point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons, winning five championships and an NBA Finals MVP award. He briefly retired after being diagnosed with HIV, then returned at age 36 to play 32 games before retiring again. He is also recognized as one of America's most influential black businessmen and has various business interests, including being a part-owner of the Lakers.

Tenacious D is an American comedy rock duo formed in 1994 in Los Angeles. The band consists of Jack Black and Kyle Gass and has released three albums. They gained popularity in 1997 through their eponymous TV series and supporting roles for major rock acts.

James VI and I, also known as James Stuart, ruled as King of Scotland from 1567 and as King of England and Ireland from 1603 until his death in 1625. Although he governed both countries under a personal union, they remained separate sovereign states with distinct parliaments, judiciaries, and laws. James was a proponent of a unified parliament for Scotland and England but encountered significant challenges in England, including the Gunpowder Plot and conflicts with the English Parliament.

The passage provides information about the upcoming eighteenth series of the British reality TV show Big Brother, hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley. It also gives details about Marcus Bentley's career, highlighting his role as the narrator of the UK version of Big Brother since 2000 and his recognition for his voice-over work and Geordie accent.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked federal state in Germany, bordered by five other states and two countries. It is the tenth largest state by area and sixth most populous, covering 18,413 km² with approximately 4 million inhabitants. Historically significant, its state history dates back over a millennium. Additionally, a region in Saxony is known for quality wine production, being one of the northernmost wine regions in Europe and the only one in the former East Germany.
The passage mentions East End Park, a former major league baseball park in Cincinnati's East End neighborhood, and "In the End," a song by American rock band Linkin Park.
Mel B. Brown started her solo career by releasing "I Want You Back" with Missy Elliott through Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and sister to Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

Mohra (Pawn) is an Indian action thriller film from 1994 directed by Rajiv Rai, starring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah. It was the second highest-grossing Indian film of 1994 and received nine Filmfare nominations. The film's music was particularly successful, with chart-topping songs. Initially, Divya Bharti was cast but was replaced by Raveena Tandon after her death.
The passage states that "Hourglass" is a song by the British electronic duo Disclosure and also refers to the fourteenth studio album by singer-songwriter James Taylor.

Shane Black, born December 16, 1961, is an American who has worked as a screenwriter, director, producer, and actor. He is known for writing the 1987 action film "Lethal Weapon" and for his directorial debut with "Kiss Kiss Bang Bang" in 2005.
A View to a Kill (1985) is the fourteenth film in the James Bond series and features Roger Moore in his final portrayal of James Bond.
Papua is the largest and easternmost province of Indonesia, encompassing western New Guinea. Formerly known as Irian Jaya (or West Irian/Irian Barat), it included all of Indonesian New Guinea.
The passage states that Augustus likely died of natural causes, but there were unconfirmed rumors suggesting his wife, Livia, may have poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez began her music career in 1999 with the album "On the 6" and the hit single "If You Had My Love." In 2001, she achieved a milestone by having her second studio album "J.Lo" and the film "The Wedding Planner" both reach number one in the same week. Her relationship with Ben Affleck during this period influenced her third studio album "This Is Me... Then" (2002), though it overshadowed the release of the film "Gigli," which was a failure. After marrying Marc Anthony, Lopez experienced a resurgence with the success of the film "Shall We Dance?" and later returned to prominence in 2011 as a judge on American Idol and with her hit single "On the Floor," one of the best-selling singles of all time.

The passage describes working animals, which are typically domesticated animals kept by humans and trained to perform various tasks. These tasks include guiding, providing tractive force, milking, and herding. Examples range from guide dogs to draft horses and logging elephants. The passage also notes that while wild animals can sometimes be trained for work, they rarely possess the necessary traits of trustworthiness and mild temper found in true domesticated working animals.

The passage describes two distinct topics: a 1998 comedy film titled "Billboard Dad" starring Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen, and two record charts published by Billboard magazine—Top Latin Albums, which focuses on Spanish language albums, and Regional Mexican Albums, which is genre-specific for Mexican music in the U.S.

The passage describes Vedam, an Indian drama film released in 2010 in the Telugu language. It was written and directed by Radhakrishna Jagarlamudi and stars a cast including Allu Arjun, Manoj Manchu, Anushka Shetty, Manoj Bajpayee, Saranya Ponvannan, Deeksha Seth, Lekha Washington, and Siya Gautham.

Men in Black II is a 2002 American science fiction action comedy film featuring an ensemble cast including Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, Lara Flynn Boyle, Johnny Knoxville, Rosario Dawson, Tony Shalhoub, and Rip Torn.

Sancho Panza is a fictional character from Don Quixote, authored by Miguel de Cervantes in 1605. He serves as Don Quixote's squire and offers humorous comments known as "sanchismos," which blend humor, proverbs, and wit.

The passage describes "The Adventures of Pluto Nash," a 2002 film that is an Australian-American collaboration, classified as a science fiction action comedy. It features Eddie Murphy in a dual role and was directed by Ron Underwood.
The world premiere of Henrik Ibsen's play "Hedda Gabler" occurred on January 31, 1891, at the Residenztheater in Munich, with Ibsen in attendance.
Brazzers is a pornographic production company located in Montreal, Canada.
Timothy Simon Roth, born on May 14, 1961, is an English actor and director.

Juve, or Juventus Football Club S.p.A., is an Italian football club founded in 1897 in Turin, Piedmont. It is the second-oldest active football club in Italy, after Genoa's section formed in 1893. The club is known for its black and white striped home kit, which it has worn since 1903, and currently plays its home matches at the 41,507-capacity Juventus Stadium.

Viola Davis appeared in supporting and minor roles in films and television shows during the late 1990s and early 2000s, including "Kate & Leopold" (2001), "Far from Heaven" (2002), and "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit."

Jenna Jameson, born Jenna Marie Massoli on April 9, 1974, is an American entrepreneur, webcam model, and former pornographic film actress. The passage provides information about Kelly Preston's filmography, mentioning that she starred in "Broken Bridges" alongside Toby Keith, Lindsey Haun, and Burt Reynolds. It also notes that she appeared in other films such as "The Cat in the Hat" and "Old Dogs."
Kesha Rose Sebert, born on March 1, 1987, is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper. Her name is sometimes stylized as Ke $ ha.
The passage describes the release dates of two versions of "Despacito" on May 5, 2017: one electronic version produced by Major Lazer and MOSKA, and one urban version produced by Sky.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000 by the NWA and later WCW. Initially broadcast via closed-circuit television, it became the first NWA event to be broadcast on pay-per-view in 1987 after the WWF's Survivor Series demanded exclusivity. The event continued as a pay-per-view until 2000. In 2014, the WWE Network included closed-circuit broadcasts from 1983-1986 in its pay-per-view section and rated them TV-MA for violence.
Veeru Devgan is an Indian professional in the film industry, specializing as a stunt and action choreographer and film director in Bollywood.
Star Trek: Discovery is the first series created for the streaming service and marks the return of a Star Trek series after the conclusion of Star Trek: Enterprise in 2005.

Terry Crews played as a defensive end and linebacker in the NFL for the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers, and Washington Redskins, and also played for the Rhein Fire in the World League of American Football.

The passage provides information about three distinct topics: 
1. "Excuse My French" - an American rapper's debut studio album released in 2014.
2. A 2014 Egyptian comedy film titled "Excuse My French," directed by Amr Salama.
3. Benjamin Paul Ballance-Drew, also known as Plan B or Ben Drew, a British hip hop artist with additional roles as an actor, film director, and producer.
A floppy disk, also known as a diskette or simply disk, is a type of disk storage made from a thin, flexible magnetic medium enclosed in a plastic carrier lined with fabric to remove dust particles.

From the mid-19th century to 1996, Guatemala faced significant political instability and civil conflict. This period included a prolonged civil war from 1960 to 1996, during which the U.S.-backed government clashed with leftist rebels. The conflict was marked by severe human rights abuses, notably genocidal massacres of the Maya population carried out by the military.

Forceps, often referred to as tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps, are handheld, hinged instruments used for grasping and holding objects. They are commonly used in medicine but have various names outside of medical contexts.
The passage indicates that The Closer started its seventh and final season on July 11, 2011, and had concluded its sixth season as the highest-rated drama on cable television.

The passage describes Dr. Jack Shephard, a fictional character and protagonist from the ABC television series Lost, portrayed by Matthew Fox. Lost is an American drama series that aired from 2004 to 2010, spanning six seasons with 121 episodes. The first season attracted approximately 16 million viewers per episode on ABC.

Matthew David McConaughey, born on November 4, 1969, is an American actor who has focused on dramatic roles since 2011, appearing in films such as The Lincoln Lawyer, Bernie, Killer Joe, The Paperboy, Mud, Magic Mike, The Wolf of Wall Street, Dallas Buyers Club, Interstellar, and Free State of Jones. He starred in the 2012 film Mud alongside Tye Sheridan, Jacob Lofland, Sam Shepard, and Reese Witherspoon.

The passage summarizes Robert Palmer's career, highlighting his work as a writer, particularly his book "Deep Blues," his contributions to music journalism for major publications like the New York Times and Rolling Stone, his involvement in producing blues recordings and the soundtrack for the film "Deep Blues," and his past musical career as a clarinet player in the band the Insect Trust during the 1960s.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum (1912-1986) was an American sculptor, photographer, author, and engineer, most noted for completing the Mount Rushmore National Memorial after his father, Gutzon Borglum, died in 1941. Gutzon Borglum initially designed and led the project from 1927 to 1941, with Lincoln assisting. After his father's death, Lincoln took over and finished the memorial.

The passage provides details about the film "Underdog," including its director (Frederik Du Chau), writers (Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams), and main cast members (Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton). It also mentions the voice talents for the film (Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett).

The TV series "The 100" centers around a group of teens—Clarke Griffin, Bellamy Blake, Octavia Blake, Jasper Jordan, Monty Green, Raven Reyes, Finn Collins, John Murphy, and Wells Jaha—who are among the first survivors from a space habitat called "The Ark" to return to Earth after a nuclear apocalypse. The series also explores the roles of key adults including Dr. Abby Griffin (Clarke's mother), Marcus Kane (a council member on the Ark), and Thelonious Jaha (the Chancellor of the Ark and Wells' father).

The Concert for Bangladesh is acknowledged as a successful and influential humanitarian aid project that raised awareness and funds. Despite facing financial issues due to its pioneering nature, it inspired subsequent events like Live Aid and offered valuable lessons.
Mani Ratnam is recognized as one of India's influential filmmakers, known for revolutionizing the Tamil film industry and enhancing the profile of Indian cinema.

The Freeport Doctrine was stated by Stephen A. Douglas during the second Lincoln-Douglas debate on August 27, 1858, in Freeport, Illinois. This debate was part of a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the U.S. Senate from Illinois, and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas.
